clues: This city is home to a famous tower that sparkles every night.
Known as the 'City of Love' and a hub for fashion and art.
fun_fact: The Eiffel Tower was supposed to be dismantled after 20 years but was saved because it was useful for radio transmissions!
Paris has only one stop sign in the entire city—most intersections rely on priority-to-the-right rules.
trivia: This city is famous for its croissants and macarons. Bon appétit!
Paris was originally a Roman city called Lutetia.

clues: This city has the busiest pedestrian crossing in the world.
You can visit an entire district dedicated to anime, manga, and gaming.
fun_fact: Tokyo was originally a small fishing village called Edo before becoming the bustling capital it is today!
More than 14 million people live in Tokyo, making it one of the most populous cities in the world.
trivia: The city has over 160,000 restaurants, more than any other city in the world.
Tokyo’s subway system is so efficient that train delays of just a few minutes come with formal apologies.

clues: Home to a green statue gifted by France in the 1800s.
Nicknamed 'The Big Apple' and known for its Broadway theaters.
fun_fact: The Statue of Liberty was originally a copper color before oxidizing to its iconic green patina.
Times Square was once called Longacre Square before being renamed in 1904.
trivia: New York City has 468 subway stations, making it one of the most complex transit systems in the world.
The Empire State Building has its own zip code: 10118.

clues: Home to a famous clock tower that is often mistaken for its bell.
This city has a royal palace where the king resides.
fun_fact: Big Ben actually refers to the bell inside the clock tower, not the tower itself!
London has over 170 museums, including the British Museum, which has artifacts from around the world.
trivia: The London Underground is the oldest subway system in the world, opened in 1863.
Buckingham Palace has over 700 rooms!

clues: An ancient city famous for its gladiators and massive amphitheater.
This city is home to an independent country within its borders.
fun_fact: The Colosseum could hold up to 50,000 spectators in ancient times!
Vatican City, the smallest country in the world, is located within Rome.
trivia: Ancient Romans used urine as a mouthwash because of its ammonia content!
Rome has a fountain that collects millions of euros in coins every year—Trevi Fountain!

clues: This city has the world's tallest building.
Famous for its artificial islands shaped like palm trees.
fun_fact: The Burj Khalifa is so tall that people on the top floors see the sunset a few minutes later than those on the ground.
Dubai’s police force has luxury supercars like Ferraris and Lamborghinis.
trivia: Before oil was discovered, Dubai was a small fishing and pearl-diving town.
The city has an indoor ski resort, despite being in a desert!

clues: This city has a world-famous opera house with a unique sail-like design.
It’s home to one of the world’s largest natural harbors.
fun_fact: The Sydney Opera House took 14 years to build and was initially estimated to cost $7 million, but ended up costing $102 million!
Sydney’s Bondi Beach was one of the first places in the world to introduce surf lifesaving.
trivia: Sydney's harbor is so large that it could fit all of the world’s navies combined.
The city was originally a British penal colony established in 1788.

clues: Famous for its massive statue of Jesus on a mountain.
Hosts one of the biggest carnival celebrations in the world.
fun_fact: Rio’s Christ the Redeemer statue was struck by lightning in 2014, damaging its thumb!
The Maracanã Stadium once held the record for the highest attendance at a football match.
trivia: The name ‘Rio de Janeiro’ means ‘River of January’ in Portuguese.
The city’s Copacabana Beach has millions of visitors every year.

clues: This city has one of the busiest ports in the world.
Famous for a waterfront area called The Bund, featuring historic and modern skyscrapers.
fun_fact: Shanghai has the fastest commercial train in the world, the Maglev, which reaches speeds of 431 km/h (268 mph).
The city’s name means ‘Upon the Sea’ in Chinese.
trivia: Shanghai is home to the world’s second-tallest building, the Shanghai Tower.
The city has more than 24 million residents, making it one of the most populous in the world.

clues: This city is the only one in the world that spans two continents.
It was once known as Constantinople and was the capital of the Byzantine Empire.
fun_fact: The Grand Bazaar in Istanbul is one of the oldest and largest covered markets in the world, with over 4,000 shops.
Istanbul has been the capital of three great empires: Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman.
trivia: The Bosphorus Strait separates the European and Asian sides of the city.
Tulips, often associated with the Netherlands, actually originated in Turkey.

clues: This city is home to a colorful cathedral with onion-shaped domes.
It has the deepest metro system in the world.
fun_fact: Moscow’s Metro stations are so beautifully designed that they are sometimes called ‘underground palaces.’
Red Square got its name from an old Russian word meaning ‘beautiful,’ not the color or communism.
trivia: Moscow is home to the Kremlin, a massive fortress that houses the government.
The city has more billionaires than any other city except New York.

clues: Home to the world’s largest film industry by production volume.
This city has the Gateway of India, a famous colonial-era monument.
fun_fact: Mumbai was originally a group of seven islands before land reclamation connected them into one city.
The city’s train network carries more than 7.5 million people daily!
trivia: Mumbai’s dabbawalas deliver thousands of home-cooked meals every day with remarkable accuracy, using a system studied by business schools worldwide.
The name ‘Mumbai’ comes from the local goddess Mumbadevi.

clues: Famous for its Hollywood sign and movie industry.
This city has sunny weather almost all year round.
fun_fact: Los Angeles is home to the world’s shortest railway, the Angels Flight funicular, which is only 298 feet long.
The city’s original name was ‘El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora la Reina de los Ángeles de Porciúncula.’
trivia: Los Angeles is one of the most diverse cities in the world, with residents speaking over 200 languages.
The Hollywood Walk of Fame has more than 2,700 stars honoring celebrities.
